Authors:
Bożena Zakryś, Anna Karnkowska-Ishikawa, Maja
Łukomska-Kowalczyk, Rafał Milanowski
Title:
New photosynthetic euglenoid isolated in Poland: Euglenaria
clepsydroides sp. nova (Euglenea).
Keywords:
Euglenaria clepsydroides sp. nov; Euglena undulata;
Euglena gymnodinioides; Lepocinclis constricta; rDNA; taxonomy
Abstract:
In this paper, we describe a new photosynthetic euglenoid
species, Euglenaria clepsydroides Zakryś, found in Poland. A large
population of this species exists in a few, small, eutrophic bodies of
water inside the Masurian Landscape Park (covering a part of the
Masurian Lake District in Poland). The characteristic and atypical
(hourglass-like) cell shape sets it well apart from the other species
that have been described up to now. This atypical cell shape has so far
been observed only in three species: Lepocinclis constricta Matvienko
1938, Euglena undulata Kato 1983 and Euglena gymnodinioides Zakryś 1986,
whose other morphological characteristics, however (such as the number
and morphology of chloroplasts, the lack of mucocysts), as well as data
from SSU rDNA sequence analysis, exclude the possibility that they may
be close relatives of Euglenaria clepsydroides. On the phylogenetic
tree, the new species is situated within the Euglenaria, clade. While it
is a sister group of the clade that includes representatives of
Euglenaria anabaena, the two species are clearly morphologically
distinct.
